sections.section: This tutorial provides a relatively simple message flow in an application that is designed to receive a JSON input message over HTTP. Five input messages are provided which exercise different branches of logic in the message flow. A Test Project is also provided, which contains nine test cases. Each test case tests a single message flow node using a NodeSpy. Where required, Message Assembly files (.mxml) are provided which describe the expected output from each test case.

The tutorial describes how to run the provided test cases agains the message flow using the default options for running an Integration Server JUnit. The tutorial then describes how you can run a single isolated test case, and use other more complex configuration options such as turning tracing on and how to run tests in an integration server which uses an existing work directory.

sections.section: Click Import and two projects will be added to your workspace. The application named MyApplicationUnderTest provides a single message flow named MyMessageFlowUnderTest which receives data over HTTP. The test project named MyTestProject contains eighteen example message assembly files, and nine unit tests.
The message flow named MyMessageFlowUnderTest expects to receive input JSON messages which conform to the JSON schema named InputMessageSchema.json which you will find in the same application.
Now move to the Prepare section where we will explore the provided message flow, test data and the Test Project's test cases in detail.

sections.section:
The message flow expects to receive JSON data over HTTP. Each message carries three string properties named FirstName, LastName and Country for a fictitious person. The Country field uses a two character abbreviation for a country. Four example valid input messages are saved in the application for use with the Flow Exerciser:
{"FirstName": "Jean", "LastName": "Dupont", "Country":"FR"}
{"FirstName": "Joe", "LastName": "Bloggs", "Country":"GB"}
{"FirstName": "John", "LastName": "Doe", "Country":"US"}
{"FirstName": "Otto", "LastName": "Normalverbraucher", "Country":"DE"}
One example invalid input message is saved in the application for use with the Flow Exerciser:
This message is deliberately not valid JSON
These input messages have been used to capture Message Assembly files which describe what the logical tree looks like for each step of the message flow. If you would like, you can use these inputs with the Flow Exerciser to become familiar with the behavior of the message flow. This is not a mandatory step for the tutorial - as we have already taken this message data and used it to create test cases which will be executed later in the tutorial - but it may help with your understanding of the scenario.

Nine Test Cases have been defined inside the Test Project MyTestProject in the java file named MyApplicationUnderTest_MyFlowUnderTest_UnitTests.java. You can open this file to familiarise yourself with the detail of the test cases. In summary their purpose is as follows:
TestCase01: Test the MappingError node to ensure it transforms data correctly
TestCase02: Test the Route node to ensure a message with Country=FR is routed to the default output terminal
TestCase03: Test the MappingDefault node to ensure it transforms data correctly
TestCase04: Test the Route node to ensure a message with Country=GB is routed to the GB output terminal
TestCase05: Test the MappingGB node to ensure it transforms data correctly
TestCase06: Test the Route node to ensure a message with Country=US is routed to the US output terminal
TestCase07: Test the MappingUS node to ensure it transforms data correctly
TestCase08: Test the Route node to ensure a message with Country=DE is routed to the DE output terminal
TestCase09: Test the MappingDE node to ensure it transforms data correctly
Now move to the Run section where we will execute the tests and explore more detailed configuration which controls how the Toolkit runs the tests in a Test Project.

sections.section: Edit the Compute node ESQL to generate the JSON output

details.details:
Open PurchaseFlow_Compute.esql in the application ExampleTestDrivenDevelopment. Change the code as follows:
  CREATE FUNCTION Main() RETURNS BOOLEAN
  BEGIN
    DECLARE Total DECIMAL 0;
    DECLARE PurchaseRef REFERENCE TO InputRoot.XMLNSC.MyOrder.Items;
    MOVE PurchaseRef FIRSTCHILD;
    WHILE LASTMOVE(PurchaseRef) DO
      SET Total = Total + PurchaseRef;
      MOVE PurchaseRef NEXTSIBLING;
    END WHILE;
    SET OutputRoot.Properties = InputRoot.Properties;
    SET OutputRoot.JSON.Data.Name = InputRoot.XMLNSC.MyOrder.Name;
    SET OutputRoot.JSON.Data.Total = Total;
    RETURN TRUE;
  END;
Save and close the ESQL file.

sections.section: Run the provided unit test again which should now PASS

details.details: Right-click the test project ExampleTestDrivenDevelopment_IntegrationTest and choose the option to Run Test Project. Just like before, after a few seconds, an integration server will be started which runs the test. This time the results will report that the test has now succeeded, because the message flow logic now correctly generates the JSON output tree which matches to the Message Assembly file which we created earlier in the tutorial.

sections.section: This tutorial has shown how to use the message assembly editor and do test driven development whilst developing message flows.
